case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 1119-1122 of 1973 and 816 to 835 of 1974

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1119-1122 of 1973 and 816 to 835 of 1974 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1119-1122 of 1973 and 816 to 835 of 1974. From the judgment and order dated the 9th December, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in Spl. Appeals Nos. 658, 664, 674 and 678/1968, and 653-657, 659-660, 663, 667, 669-673, 677, 678-680 and 685-686/1968 respectively.

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated 9th December 1971 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 658, 664, 674, 678/1968 and others.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and order dated the 9th December, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in Spl. Appeals Nos. 658, 664, 674 and 678/1968, and 653-657, 659-660, 663, 667, 669-673, 677, 678-680 and 685-686/1968 respectively. N. Phadke,  In C. A. No. 1119/73 , B. Sen  In C, A. Nos. 1120-1122/73  and D. N. Mishra, for the, appellants  In As. Nos. 1119-1122/73 .

facts.text: State Transport Undertaking of Uttar Pradesh framed four schemes for four routes under Chapter IVA of Motor Vehicles Act 1939.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals stem out of a litigation which germinated from a certain nationalisation scheme contemplated in Chapter IVA of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 (Act IV of 1939) hereinafter called the Act. More than a decade ago, the State Transport Undertaking of Uttar Pradesh (hereinafter referred to as the Undertaking, for short) took steps for framing four schemes for four routes and proceeded to publish the necessary notifications in the Uttar Pradesh Gazette, copies whereof were sent to Rajasthan for being pasted on the notice boards of the Transport Authorities in that State.

facts.text: Notifications published in Uttar Pradesh Gazette, copies sent to Rajasthan for pasting on notice boards of Transport Authorities.

anchor.surface_text: More than a decade ago, the State Transport Undertaking of Uttar Pradesh (hereinafter referred to as the Undertaking, for short) took steps for framing four schemes for four routes and proceeded to publish the necessary notifications in the Uttar Pradesh Gazette, copies whereof were sent to Rajasthan for being pasted on the notice boards of the Transport Authorities in that State. A statutory enquiry, envisaged in Chapter IVA, followed.

facts.text: Statutory enquiry under Chapter IVA followed publication.

anchor.surface_text: A statutory enquiry, envisaged in Chapter IVA, followed. Some operators-not the appellants--raised objections and, eventually, the schemes were approved.

facts.text: Some operators, not the appellants, raised objections to the schemes.

anchor.surface_text: Some operators-not the appellants--raised objections and, eventually, the schemes were approved. Of course these schemes related to interstate routes and had received the concurrence of the State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Schemes related to interstate routes and received concurrence of State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: Of course these schemes related to interstate routes and had received the concurrence of the State of Rajasthan. Although the Act contemplates the framing of schemes for nationalisation for the obvious benefit of the traveling public by provision of an efficient, adequate, economical and properly coordinated road transport service affords statutory opportunity for raising objections and making representations, not merely to the affected operators but also to other entities like associations representing persons interested in the provision of road transport facilities, local authorities, police authorities etc.

facts.text: Only private operators raised voice against the proposed schemes.

anchor.surface_text: in the present case only private operators have raised their voice against the proposed schemes. While it may look a little odd for such operators to plead in Court that public bodies and passengers associations in Rajasthan have been denied opportunities of making effective representation, that does not detract from the obligation of this Court to consider whether obligatory procedural requisites prescribed by the statute have been adhered to in the process of nationalising the inter-State route concerned.

facts.text: Schemes relate to nationalisation of inter-State route Agra (U.P.) to Bharatpur (Rajasthan).

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, these appeals relate to the validity of a scheme of nationalisation of an inter-State route stretching across Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan. The identical scheme was challenged, without success, on certain constitutional grounds by a number of operators and this Court negatived those contentions in its decision reported as Khazan Singh v. State of U.P.

facts.text: Identical scheme challenged on constitutional grounds in Khazan Singh v. State of U.P., Supreme Court negatived contentions.

anchor.surface_text: The identical scheme was challenged, without success, on certain constitutional grounds by a number of operators and this Court negatived those contentions in its decision reported as Khazan Singh v. State of U.P. A few grounds, not urged before this Court in the earlier round, however, survive for our consideration.

facts.text: Undertaking contemplated scheme excluding private operators from route Agra (U.P.) to Bharatpur (Rajasthan).

anchor.surface_text: The facts pertaining to the questions we propose to deal with lend themselves to a brief statement. The Undertaking contemplated framing of a scheme excluding private operators from the route Agra (in U.P.) to Bharatpur (in Rajasthan). Admittedly, the scheme which was published in the official gazette of the State of U.P. on December 9, 1961

facts.text: Scheme published in official gazette of State of U.P. on December 9, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the scheme which was published in the official gazette of the State of U.P. on December 9, 1961 was not published in the Gazette of Rajasthan. Section 68C enables State Transport Undertakings to prepare schemes totally or partially excluding private operators from bus routes.

facts.text: Scheme was not published in the Gazette of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the scheme which was published in the official gazette of the State of U.P. on December 9, 1961 was not published in the Gazette of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Rule 4 was complied with; notices put up on notice boards of State Transport Authorities of Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested that the Rules had not been complied with but, in the light of the categorical statement in the judgment under appeal to the contrary, there is no merit in this argument. The High Court has stated It is not disputed that this Rule (Rule 4) was complied with. The notices were put up on the notice board of the State Transport Authorities of Uttar Pradesh and also of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Bus operators were aware of the details of the scheme as they were plying buses between Agra and Bharatpur.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned by the High Court, the bus operators who claim to be aggrieved by the non-publication in the Rajasthan Official Gazette were otherwise very probably aware of the details of the scheme since they were plying their buses between the two termini located in Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Publication complied with in official gazette of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the question of adequacy or otherwise of notice to the respondents, sections 68C and 68D provide for publication, in the official gazette of the State. This provision was complied with and the notifications were published in the official gazette of the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Schemes approved after objections.

anchor.surface_text: Some operators-not the appellants--raised objections and, eventually, the schemes were approved.

facts.text: Earlier appeals confined to constitutional issues under Art. 132.

anchor.surface_text: As was rightly pointed out by Mr. Phadke, learned counsel for some of the appellants and also by Mr. B. Sen, appearing for the others, the earlier decision was rendered in appeals pursuant to certificates granted under Art. 132(1) of the Constitution. Necessarily they were confined to constitutional issues.

facts.text: Present appeals raise non-conformity with statutory mandates, not constitutional invalidity.

anchor.surface_text: The present points do not savor of constitutional invalidity, but of illegality for non-conformity with statutory mandates.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds non-publication in Rajasthan Gazette not fatal flaw.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the failure to publish in the Official Gazette of Rajasthan, is a fatal flaw. There is no doubt, as has been pointed out by the High Court, that the operators who are contesting the scheme before us could not have been in ignorance of the anatomy of the scheme impugned.

facts.text: U.P. Undertaking proposed the scheme, published in U.P. Gazette as required.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it was the U.P. Undertaking which proposed the scheme for nationalisation and the U.P. Gazette has carried the publication. The law asks for no more. The legal objection has therefore to be overruled.

facts.text: Argument that U.P. authorities could not cancel permits of Rajasthan bus operators rejected by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: A point was raised that the authorities in the State of Uttar Pradesh could not validly cancel permits held by bus operators of Rajasthan. This argument has engaged the attention of the Division Bench of the High Court and has been rejected, for reasons stated, which meet with our concurrence.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

issues.text: Whether the schemes were published in compliance with Rule 4 of the rules regarding pasting on notice boards of transport authorities including in Rajasthan?

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 which provides that schemes framed under S. 68C of the Act shall be published in form appended to the Rules. The Transport Commissioner is obligated to get a copy of the scheme pasted on the notice board of the office of the State Transport Authority and another at the office of the Regional Transport Authority concerned. It was suggested that the Rules had not been complied with but,

issues.text: Whether publication of the scheme in the Official Gazette of Rajasthan was mandatory under Section 68C for an inter-State route scheme initiated by the Uttar Pradesh State Transport Undertaking?

anchor.surface_text: Even so, let us examine whether there has been any contravention of the vital formality in S. 68C regarding publication in the Official Gazette. The point was taken in the High Court, but was disposed of in the following manner As regards the question of adequacy or otherwise of notice to the respondents, sections 68C and 68D provide for publication,

anchor.surface_text: A point was raised that the authorities in the State of Uttar Pradesh could not validly cancel permits held by bus operators of Rajasthan. This argument has engaged the attention of the Division Bench of the High Court and has been rejected, for reasons stated, which meet with our concurrence.

arguments.claim: Nationalisation schemes delayed by private operators harm public interest and coordinated transport

anchor.surface_text: It is surprising that a nationalisation scheme, calculated to provide efficient and coordinated transport services to the common people of backward areas has got bogged down on some ground or other for over a decade.

holdings.text: The Rules regarding publication, particularly Rule 4, were complied with as notices were put up on the notice boards of the State Transport Authorities of Uttar Pradesh and also of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested that the Rules had not been complied with but, in the light of the categorical statement in the judgment under appeal to the contrary, there is no merit in this argument. The High Court has stated It is not disputed that this Rule (Rule 4) was complied with. The notices were put up on the notice board of the State Transport Authorities of Uttar Pradesh and also of Rajasthan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Categorical statement in High Court judgment confirms compliance; no merit in contrary suggestion.

holdings.text: Publication of the scheme in the Official Gazette of Rajasthan was not mandatory under Section 68C; publication in the Official Gazette of the initiating State (U.P.) is sufficient even for inter-State routes.

anchor.surface_text: construed strictly, S. 68C insists on publication of the particulars relating to a scheme intra-State or inter-State-in the Official Gazette. The base State or the undertaking which launches the proposed nationalisation alone falls within the ambit of the provision. It is clear from a perusal of S. 68C that it speaks of the State Government, the Official Gazette and the State Transport Undertaking, even though it is quite clear that inter-State schemes also come within the compass of the provision. Whatever the reason-it is not for us to ask why-the section, as it reads, merely requires publication in the concerned Official Gazette of the State whose undertaking initiates the project for nationalisation. The fact that for statutory construction the singular includes the plural, does not compel us to read the plural wherever the singular is mentioned. We are satisfied that the expression in the Official Gazette and the publication required therein, does not undergo a change in its semantics when the route concerned is an inter-State as against an intraState one. In the present case it was the U.P. Undertaking which proposed the scheme for nationalisation and the U.P. Gazette has carried the publication. The law asks for no more. The legal objection has therefore to be overruled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict construction of S.68C limits publication to Official Gazette of the State/undertaking initiating the scheme; singular 'Gazette' not read as plural; Rule 4 supplements notice.

holdings.text: The authorities in the State of Uttar Pradesh could validly cancel permits held by bus operators of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: A point was raised that the authorities in the State of Uttar Pradesh could not validly cancel permits held by bus operators of Rajasthan. This argument has engaged the attention of the Division Bench of the High Court and has been rejected, for reasons stated, which meet with our concurrence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench of High Court rejected the argument for reasons stated, with which Supreme Court concurs.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All legal objections overruled; schemes valid.

holdings.text: It may be desirable for State Transport Undertakings to publish inter-State nationalisation schemes in Official Gazettes of all States through which the route runs, but failure to do so does not invalidate the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It has been stated at the Bar that it may be desirable for State Transport Undertakings when they propose schemes for nationalisation of inter-State routes to get them published in the Official Gazettes of all the States through which the route runs. It is for the legislature to make the necessary amendatory provision in this behalf. However, for reasons already set out, we cannot invalidate the scheme on the score of its non-publication in the Rajasthan Gazette.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Desirable practice suggested but not legally required under current law; legislature to amend if needed.

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested that the Rules had not been complied with but, in the light of the categorical statement in the judgment under appeal to the contrary, there is no merit in this argument. The High Court has stated It is not disputed that this Rule (Rule 4) was complied with. The notices were put up on the notice board of the State Transport Authorities of Uttar Pradesh and also of Rajasthan.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: construed strictly, S. 68C insists on publication of the particulars relating to a scheme intra-State or inter-State-in the Official Gazette. The base State or the undertaking which launches the proposed nationalisation alone falls within the ambit of the provision. It is clear from a perusal of S. 68C that it speaks of the State Government, the Official Gazette and the State Transport Undertaking, even though it is quite clear that inter-State schemes also come within the compass of the provision. Whatever the reason-it is not for us to ask why-the section, as it reads, merely requires publication in the concerned Official Gazette of the State whose undertaking initiates the project for nationalisation. The fact that for statutory construction the singular includes the plural, does not compel us to read the plural wherever the singular is mentioned. We are satisfied that the expression in the Official Gazette and the publication required therein, does not undergo a change in its semantics when the route concerned is an inter-State as against an intraState one. In the present case it was the U.P. Undertaking which proposed the scheme for nationalisation and the U.P. Gazette has carried the publication. The law asks for no more. The legal objection has therefore to be overruled.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: A point was raised that the authorities in the State of Uttar Pradesh could not validly cancel permits held by bus operators of Rajasthan. This argument has engaged the attention of the Division Bench of the High Court and has been rejected, for reasons stated, which meet with our concurrence.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
